data.name: Barracuda
data.description: Barracuda is a spam filter, block list, and firewall promoted for businesses, headquartered in California. Mail is routed through mailservers owned by Barracuda before it's passed along to the recipient domain's mailservers for final delivery. The recipient is able to manage a lot of delivery settings such as allow lists, but sender reputation issues that affect all Barracuda customers globally may require contacting Barracuda support directly to resolve.

codes.description: The mail server encountered a temporary failure. If the command is repeated without any change, it might be completed. Mail servers can use temporary failures like this to keep untrusted senders at bay.

responses.response: smtp;421 Temporary failure, please try again later.
responses.description: This response is followed by the bounce received from one of the intended recipients of the message. You'll want to resolve the delivery issue for the quoted recipient before sending to this group of addresses again.
The recepient domain uses a Barracuda mail filter and their license for that service is expired. They'll need to resolve their license issue with Barracuda to start to receive messages again.

codes.description: The mail server encountered a temporary failure. If the command is repeated without any change, it might be completed. Mail servers can use temporary failures like this to keep untrusted senders at bay.

The mail server encountered a temporary failure. If the command is repeated without any change, it might be completed. Mail servers can use temporary failures like this to keep untrusted senders at bay.

responses.response: smtp;450 cuda_nsu 4.7.1 <email@example.com>: Recipient address rejected: Policy Rejection- Abuse. Go away.
responses.description: If you know the recipient personally, try reaching out through other means to confirm why the message was rejected (include the full source and headers of the rejected message). Only the recipient and their mailserver admin can resolve this bounce.

codes.description: The mail server encountered a temporary failure. If the command is repeated without any change, it might be completed. Mail servers can use temporary failures like this to keep untrusted senders at bay.

responses.response: smtp;451 4.7.1 <email@example.com>: Recipient address rejected: Greylisted for 5 minutes
smtp;451 cuda_nsu 4.4.3 Temporary server error. Please try again later

codes.description: The transaction failed permanently. The server will not try to send the message again.

responses.response: smtp;554 rejected due to spam URL in content
responses.description: A URL in your message content may be on a public or private block list. Some recipients may also filter URLs based on their geo-location. Check all of the domains, subdomains, and full URLs in your content against as many public lists as you can to narrow-down the culprit.

Check your content, phrasing, and links for any potentially suspicious characteristics. Even something as simple as an unfortunate typo or a link to an exploited webpage can block a message from delivering.

codes.description:
The transaction failed permanently. The server will not try to send the message again. This is used as a general error code, so there are many reasons why you could be seeing it.

Itâ€™s common for email service providers to add a status code (5.1.1) after the SMTP reply code (smtp;550) for additional categorization of the issue.

responses.description: This mailbox does not exist at this mail server. Check to make sure there are no typos with the address.
This mailbox does not exist at this mail server. Check to make sure there are no typos with the address.

Barracuda states that a 550 SMTP code means that the requested command failed because the user's mailbox was unavailable (for example, because it was not found, or because the command was rejected for policy reasons).
Barracuda thinks you're attempting to impersonate a known brand. Check your sending domains, 'From' details, and content and links for potential unintended references.

responses.response: smtp;550 cuda_nsu 5.4.1 [email@example.com]: Recipient address rejected: Access denied [example.com]
responses.description: Recipient address rejected: Blocked indicates that the recipient's email address has been added to the Barracuda's customizable blocklist.

otherProviders.name: Mimecast
otherProviders.description: Mimecast is a spam filter, block list, and firewall solution for promoted for businesses, headquartered in London. Mail is routed through mailservers owned by Mimecast (*.mimecast.com) before it's passed along to the recipient domain's mailservers for final delivery. The recipient is able to manage a lot of delivery settings such as spam policy levels and overrides (allow lists).

otherProviders.name: Proofpoint
otherProviders.description: Proofpoint is a spam filter, block list, and firewall promoted for businesses, headquartered in California. Mail is routed through mailservers owned by Proofpoint (*.ppe-hosted.com) before it's passed along to the recipient domain's mailservers for final delivery. The recipient is able to manage a lot of delivery settings such a allow lists and spam filtering policy levels. For globally-blocked IPs, the adminstrator of the IP will need to request delisting directly.

otherProviders.name: Email Security.cloud
otherProviders.description: "Email Security.cloud" is a product working in combination with "Symantec Messaging Gateway" as part of a range of services offered by Broadcom, headquartered in California. It features spam filtering, firewall protection, and block lists with resource guides of detailed troubleshooting steps for email delivery. Additionally, a legitimate email which has been incorrectly given a verdict of spam can be submitted to Symantec for analysis and filter review.

otherProviders.name: ZeroSpam
otherProviders.description: ZeroSpam is a spam filter, block list, and firewall promoted for businesses, headquartered in Quebec. Mail is routed through mailservers owned by ZeroSpam before it's passed along to the recipient domain's mailservers for final delivery. The recipient is able to manage a lot of delivery settings such as allow lists, but senders may also be able to contact a postmaster@zerospam.com and abuse@zerospam.com address to get more in-depth analysis.

otherProviders.name: Cisco
otherProviders.description: "Cisco Secure Email" is a spam filter, block list, and firewall solution promoted for businesses, headquartered in California. Mail is routed through mailservers owned by Cisco (imphmx.com) before it's passed along to the recipient domain's mailservers for final delivery. The recipient is able to manage a lot of delivery settings such a allow lists, so it helps to ask the recipient to run the described debugging tests in Cisco's User Guide to identify and resolve delivery issues.

otherProviders.name: Exchange Online
otherProviders.description: Exchange Online an email provider, headquartered in Washington as part of Microsoft. It's offered by both Office 365 and Microsoft 365, providing businesses with spam filtering, block lists, and firewall protection. If a message is going to spam or getting blocked, there are typically instructions for the email admin to fix the specific error in Exchange documentation.
